title: Testing the feasibility of extending the Scottish Longitudinal Study back through time
abstractText:
The Scottish Longitudinal Study (SLS) is a large sample of anonymous individuals linked through time for whom census, vital events, cancer and hospital admissions information are collected. It incorporates data from the 1991, 2001 and, eventually, the 2011 Census and beyond. It is a 5.3 per cent sample, based on 20 birth dates for approximately 270,000 individuals in Scotland. The study allows for the analysis of a range of demographic, health and social questions.

While we know much about the SLS members' lives from 1991, we know little about them previously. Nor do we know anything about their parentâ€™s circumstances, except for those parents who were living with the SLS member at the time of a Census. This exciting feasibility study will explore how we might link back to the 1939 National Register (collected for use in conscription and rationing) and to vital events registrations prior to 1974, for both the SLS members and their parents. This is uniquely possible because of the work done by the General Register Office for Scotland (GROS) to make both these datasets more accessible. We will present our results to a workshop of expert researchers who will help us evaluate the outcomes of this pilot analysis.
